intro: Coix crypsoides, commonly known as the Mexican sedge, is a flowering plant native to Central and South America. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, which includes sedges, grass-like plants with triangular stems. The plant typically grows in wetland or marshy environments, thriving in moist, well-drained soils. Its narrow, grass-like leaves and small, spike-like inflorescences are characteristic of the genus Coix. While not widely cultivated for food, it plays a role in local ecosystems and has been used in traditional medicine in some regions.
